qas.question: What is the most abundant zinc isotope?
Why is zinc oxide used in nuclear reactors?
What is used to study how alloys containing zinc wear out?
What is the only zinc isotope?
Why is zinc oxide used in atomic reactors?
What is used to study how alloys containing zinc melt?

context: <a0_0><b4_0>64Zn<b4_0/><a0_0/>, the most abundant isotope of zinc, is very susceptible to neutron activation, being transmuted into the highly radioactive 65Zn, which has a half-life of 244 days and produces <a1_0><b5_0>intense gamma radiation<b5_0/><a1_0/>. Because of this, Zinc Oxide used in nuclear reactors as an <a2_0><b6_0>anti-corrosion agent<b6_0/><a2_0/> is depleted of 64Zn before use, this is called depleted zinc oxide. For the same reason, zinc has been proposed as a salting material for nuclear weapons (cobalt is another, better-known salting material). A jacket of isotopically enriched 64Zn would be irradiated by the intense high-energy neutron flux from an exploding thermonuclear weapon, forming a large amount of <b7_0>65Zn<b7_0/> significantly increasing the radioactivity of the weapon's fallout. Such a weapon is not known to have ever been built, tested, or used. <a3_0>65Zn<a3_0/> is also used as a tracer to study how alloys that contain zinc wear out, or the path and the role of zinc in organisms.
